description:
Arachis stenosperma is a wild peanut species that belongs to the genus Arachis, which is native to South America. It is a perennial, creeping legume that typically grows close to the ground, forming dense mats.

The plant has a diploid chromosome count of 2n = 20, and it is considered one of the closest wild relatives of the cultivated peanut (Arachis hypogaea). Arachis stenosperma is known for its small, narrow pods and seeds, which is reflected in its specific epithet "stenosperma," meaning "narrow-seeded."

This wild peanut species is primarily found in the central and eastern regions of Brazil, where it thrives in sandy, well-drained soils. It has been the subject of various research efforts due to its potential to contribute valuable traits, such as disease resistance and abiotic stress tolerance, to the improvement of the cultivated peanut through breeding programs.

Arachis stenosperma is an important genetic resource for peanut breeders and researchers interested in exploring the diversity and adaptability of wild Arachis species for potential agricultural applications.
